title: OMS vs Order-Based Systems: What's the Difference?
excerpt: Understanding the distinctions between standalone OMS, order-based PSS platforms, and hybrid solutions is key to choosing the right path for airline retailing.
author: Retailaer
content:
From our reading list: Ann Cederhall cuts through the confusion around OMS terminology. This post is essential reading for any airline evaluating their technology options—the distinctions she draws between standalone OMS, order-based PSS, and hybrid solutions will save you from costly misunderstandings.

Three Approaches to Modernization

Ann demystifies the differences between three approaches to modernizing airline distribution systems:

  • Standalone OMS: Functions as a "multi-tool" overlay sitting above any PSS
  • Order-based PSS: Platforms with built-in retail capabilities
  • Hybrid solutions: Cannot operate independently from their parent PSS

What Orders Actually Enable

The real power of order structures is that they enable airlines to:

  • Combine customers with different itineraries
  • Create flexible service bundles
  • Apply dynamic discounts
  • Finally realize shopping basket functionality—rather than mere transaction processing

The Right Questions to Ask

Ann recommends airlines assess whether systems support flexible customer combinations, dynamic discounting, real bundling capabilities, and actual retail transformation—rather than pursuing technology for its own sake.

Bottom line: The technology selected matters less than whether it genuinely enables the "4 Cs"—increased sales, improved customer experience, cost reduction, and channel control.
